results.Policy Text: DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE - 2021 (DE-LPG) DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 1 of 22 CONTENTS INTRODUCTION PROGRAM OVERVIEW - 1 PROJECT PLANNING - 2 LEASING POLICY & GUIDANCE IMPACTING DESIGN - 3 SOURCE SELECTION IN FURTHER DETAIL - 4 APPENDIX - 1 PROJECT TEAM (PARTICIPANTS): ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES APPENDIX   2 DEFINITIONS APPLICABLE TO DE-LEASING 3 4 6 9 13 16 19 Commented [1]: this page will need to be correctly formatted INTRODUCTION GSA s Design Excellence Program (DE) ensures that the most appropriate expertise informs every step of the design, construction, and project-delivery processes. Since 1994, the DE Program has overseen GSA s commitment to expert-informed decision making, ensuring that the agency s investments incorporate best practices in building performance, community engagement, project management, and myriad other categories. DE s comprehensive approach to delivering best customer value has consistently achieved superior quality on time, on budget, and within scope. Following on, the successful integration of the DE Program in federally owned new construction and major modernizations, in 2001 GSA extended the DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 2 of 22 program s policies and procedures to certain lease acquisitions involving new building construction. The agency launched the Design Excellence in Leasing Program (DE-Leasing) and published an accompanying Design Excellence in Leasing Guide. This Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance (DEL-PG) updates and replaces the 2001 Design Excellence in Leasing Guide. It provides a framework for applying DE to certain lease procurements specifically Lease Construction, which is described as new building construction lease acquisitions where the Request for Lease Proposals (RLP) mandates new building construction. Lease Construction is fully defined in Chapter 14 of the PBS Leasing Desk Guide (LDG). The DEL-PG outlines the up to date best practices for integrating DE methods into qualifying projects  delivery. This guidance identifies program strategies and resources that maximize a project s benefits from its outset. It also shows how to engage agency customers and other stakeholders in a productive project dialogue, because good design welcomes maximum collaboration-which in turn fosters innovation. Guidance highlights include:     An overall process for incorporating DE into lease acquisitions involving new building construction (i.e., Lease Construction as described in this document). Information concerning project requirements and kickoff meetings, which support the definition of a project and its team members  roles.   Procedures for assembling and utilizing design reviewers effectively.   Strategies for overseeing and championing design quality pre- and -post lease award. PROGRAM OVERVIEW - 1 GSA s DE-Leasing program establishes nationwide policies and procedures for selecting the most suitable design teams for Lease Construction projects. The DE-Leasing process of reviewing submissions from offerors and their associated Architect/Engineer (A/E) firms and their lead designers ensures that projects utilize the design services of high-quality design teams. The program is also dedicated to facilitating those teams  best work:   Establishing milestones when key collaborators can synchronize DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 3 of 22 project understanding and coordinate tasks.   Means and methods for producing high-quality, high-performance facilities.   Assuring that architecture, urban design, landscape architecture, interior design, engineering, historic preservation, construction, security, sustainability, and workplace design knowledge of the Office of the Chief Architect - based Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) is appropriately integrated.   Facilitating collaboration between the leasing community and Chief Architects or designee, so that applicable leasing projects embrace a culture of quality design.   Should a region encounter Market Driven construction, first consult with the Office of Leasing for further guidance DE-Leasing shall be included in leases for lease construction as outlined more thoroughly in LDG Chapter 14. While Lease Construction represents a small percentage of GSA s lease acquisitions, there are instances when lease construction best meets customer needs. In turn, DE-Leasing creates a platform for GSA s Chief Architect or designee, SMEs, PMs, Leasing Contracting Officers (LCOs), and Leasing Specialists (LSs) to share best practices and uncover opportunities for maximizing taxpayer value. The program is a commitment to providing customer agencies with fiscally and environmentally responsible space, which creates a positive impression of the Federal Government. This DEL-PG instructs the project manager (PM) or Leasing Specialist (LS) to work with the Chief Architect) or designee to develop project specific DE requirements, as necessary. The Chief Architect or designee, will work with the project team to integrate DE principles into Lease Construction projects utilizing existing program resources and coordinate with the Chief Architect or designee as necessary. Irrespective of size or type, all Lease Construction projects require Chief Architect or designee guidance from their inception. As soon as Lease Construction has been determined, the Chief Architect or designee must be contacted by the PM and included as members of the leasing project team. The Chief Architect or designee membership in the project team ensures that a project appropriately integrates proven strategies for design quality. The Office of the Chief Architect, the Office of Leasing, the Office of Portfolio Management, and related programs collaborate regularly to deliver the best value for the American taxpayer. By articulating the partnership between the Chief Architect or designee and the leasing project team, this DEL-PG maximizes participation among all in-house experts and key stakeholders. DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 4 of 22 Department of Transportation Headquarters, Washington DC PROJECT PLANNING - 2 This section articulates the components of GSA s DE-Leasing process for Lease Construction. While modifications and adjustments of the process are permissible to address local/regional practices and procedures as necessary, DE- Leasing essentially comprises four steps:   Needs Assessment and Requirements Development   Develop and issue the RLP, including source selection criteria   Review and evaluate design submittals   Post-award design evaluation NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND REQUIREMENTS DEVELOPMENT FOR LEASE CONSTRUCTION ONLY Before commencing the project, all key stakeholders must have a thorough is best understanding of the agency s needs and requirements. This accomplished with clear requirements that may information concerning agency goals and objectives, staff and support space, adjacency needs, workspace standards and allocations, and technical room and space requirements. At a minimum, the PM should discuss these issues with the customer agency and the LCO, who thereafter must identify the requirements include DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 5 of 22 within the RLP. For Lease Construction projects, PMs should reach out to the Chief Architect or designee for guidance in determining the applicability of DE-Leasing. Preferably, the entire project team should also convene a kickoff session to clarify the following elements of design integration:   Goals and vision   Community visibility and importance   Design opportunities and criteria   Agency needs and requirements   Budget and schedule   Roles and responsibilities of the project team   Schedule and time constraints   Existing market options and opportunities NEXT STEPS Many opportunities to improve design and construction quality arise during a project s needs assessment phase and beyond. Leasing project teams should work with the Chief Architect or designee to identify different points along the lease acquisition timeline to leverage resources and maximize a project s potential. The Chief Architect or designee tailor quality assurance opportunities to the project s building type, scope, and budget while focusing on the following milestones. Advertisement - When lease construction is the known course of action, engagement with the Chief Architect or designee during this phase facilitates proper inclusion of potential DE-Leasing language in advertisements posted on BetaSAM/SAM or alternative Governmentwide point of entry (GPEs) and similar resources. Determining Approach - DE-Leasing creates collaboration between DE- Leasing representatives and the leasing project team for Lease Construction. For these projects, the Chief Architect or designee shall provide technical input and guidance in the development of DE-Leasing Source Selection evaluation factors for the RLP, Lease, and any associated documents to support an award determination. The Chief Architect or designee participates in design evaluations and, depending upon project complexity, the Chief Architect or designee may nominate staff experts, and Indefinite Delivery Indefinite Quantity (IDIQ) A/E contractors to act as technical advisors to the Source Selection Evaluation Board (SSEB). (See LDG Chapter 2, LDG Chapter 13, and LDG Chapter 14). Requirements Development - GSA s successful delivery of space depends on DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 6 of 22 shared understanding of customer requirements. The process of identifying a customer agency s strategic, functional, and technical requirements is the first step in agency delivery. Note that, while some customer agencies may have well established, highly developed requirements, others may have a Program of Requirements (POR) that requires GSA validation. DE-Leasing should also be discussed with the customer agency during this phase, and in applicable cases the PM should consult with the Chief Architect or designee to gather the strategic and technical requirements. Requirements Package   The requirements package is typically a compilation of several separate documents, forms, or other attachments that contain the detailed information necessary to produce a well crafted RLP and executed lease. The package details the DE-Leasing features and processes specific to a project. Further, it is important to understand the distinction between an agency s special requirements versus its preferences, which could be used as award factors in the procurement (e.g., 50-foot building setback required versus a 200-foot setback requested). (See the LDG for more information.) Post Award Kick-off Meeting- After award, GSA will meet with the Lessor s A/E and lead designer to convey the basis of design as outlined in the RLP. Design Intent Drawings (DID) - As a member of the leasing project team, the Chief Architect or designee provides input and guidance during the DID phase for any Lease Construction project. Design Phases - The Chief Architect or designee (or appropriate designee) participates in reviews of the following activities: schematic design; design development, and final design phases. DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 7 of 22 EPA Potomac Yards One, Arlington, VA DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 8 of 22 LEASING POLICY & GUIDANCE IMPACTING DESIGN - 3 THE LEASING DESK GUIDE (LDG) The LDG is the primary policy and lease acquisition guidance reference for real property lease acquisitions. It contains authorities, policies, technical and procedural guidance and administrative limitations governing lease acquisition. Office of Leasing professionals follow policies as they are updated or canceled via LDG revisions, Leasing Alerts, or Lease Acquisition Circulars. The LDG provides DE-Leasing guidance in the following chapters:   Chapter 1 - Requirements Development   Chapter 2 - New or Replacing Lease Acquisitions   Chapter 13 - Source Selection in Leasing   Chapter 14 - Lease Acquisitions Involving New Building Construction (Otherwise referred to as Lease Construction) As first noted in Section 1 of this document, DE-Leasing must be applied whenever the RLP specifies Lease Construction. RLPs for Lease Construction must also allow Best Value Tradeoff (BVTO); DE-Leasing is not intended for RLPs that employ a lowest price technically acceptable (LPTA) source selection. NEW BUILDING/LEASE CONSTRUCTION IN LEASING Due to the various complexities inherent to lease construction, detailed guidance ensures proper implementation of policies and processes for all scenarios. The Chief Architect or designee should familiarize themselves with the LDG, while all DE-Leasing stakeholders should understand the following leasing definitions, key terms, and concepts at a minimum. Lease Construction is more thoroughly defined in LDG Chapter-14. Lease Construction is a leasing solution when the Government mandates that only new building construction can meet its technical requirements. Such mandates are rare, issued typically when the existing market lacks highly unique (specialized) space. Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service (PBS-P100) establishes design standards and criteria for Lease Construction facilities, but only when GSA s formal RLP includes a purchase option for GSA to acquire the building at a future date determined jointly by the Office of the Chief Architect and the Office of Leasing. (See LDG Chapter-14 to learn about purchase options in detail). DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 9 of 22 RLP & LEASE CONTENT In cases of Lease Construction where DE-Leasing is incorporated, the LCO will work with the Chief Architect or designee to develop source selection evaluation factors and criteria and to review technical requirements as necessary. The RLP package includes the source selection factors and minimum requirements for lease negotiation. The RLP must describe expectations and scope that inform offerors of what to include in their proposal, as well as the factors by which proposals will be evaluated. Drafting the RLP is a critical part of any lease procurement. The process of drafting an RLP package for Lease Construction projects contains complexities discussed in the LDG. The current version of the RLP and lease documents are available on the National Office of Leasing Google site and on GSA.gov. If DE- Leasing is used, then the RLP source selection methodology must be written for a BVTO. SOURCE SELECTION The term source selection refers to selecting a source or sources as outlined in Part 570 of the General Services Administration Acquisition Manual. Source selection includes both the LPTA and BVTO processes. For additional information on source selection in leasing, refer to LDG Chapters 2, 13, and 14. If BVTO is used for a lease project that involves DE-Leasing, then there are two methods typically attributable to this process:   Single Phase - BVTO   Two Phase Design Build - BVTO Both are appropriate when an award to other than the lowest price offeror, or to the highest technically rated offeror, is the best option for the government. SINGLE PHASE - BVTO BVTO prioritizes design and designer qualifications in source selection. While it can be applied to all procurements, it should be used when technical factors are equal to or more important than price. This approach allows the Federal Government to specify certain award factors to evaluate offers beyond simply determining whether they meet the RLP s requirements; an award may be made to an offer that is higher than the lowest priced offer when that offer provides substantially more value to the Government based on the stated evaluation criteria. Single Phase BVTO employs technical award factors, with the relative ranking DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 10 of 22 and weights to help determine the successful awardee. Past performance and price must be included as award factors. The importance of the overall technical proposal to price must also be determined (e.g., substantially greater than, approximately equal to, or substantially less than price) prior to issuance of the RLP. Based on this methodology, the RLP must require offerors  design team qualifications to be submitted for review and evaluation, specifying a level of past performance information commensurate with the size, cost, and function of the procurement. The RLP may also require the initial offer submission to include interior and exterior elevations and perspectives, as well as documentation of site conditions, building positioning, views, open space information, access, setbacks, landscape design, and other important design considerations. TWO PHASE DESIGN BUILD Two-Phase Design Build BVTO is the tradeoff method that should be used when the leasing project team knows that the project will require new building construction and when customer agency requirements are well defined. It incorporates a high level of requirements for site and facility design and for the qualifications of the A/E and lead designer. Two Phase Design Build BVTO applies to lease construction that is anticipated to have a significant presence. Significant presence is associated with buildings that occupy prominent locations, that generate a high level of public traffic, and which are considered politically sensitive or highly visible. The nature of the project s surroundings can also create a significant presence. This is the case with border installations or any project that makes the building the only federally leased building, or one of few federally leased buildings, in the area. Two Phase Design Build BVTO is also appropriate in cases where the Federal Government acquires or works with a developer to acquire a site. The RLP should require the first-phase submission to include the offerors  design team qualifications (A/E firm as well as lead designer s qualifications), the offeror and design team s past performance, and site and building orientation (identifying both ingress and egress to the site). The second phase submission should include both interior and exterior elevations and perspectives, as well as documentation on site conditions, building positioning, views, open space information, access, setbacks, landscaping and other important design features. (At a minimum, interior elevations must depict common areas that include public lobby, elevator lobbies, and other spaces that include, but are not limited to, stacked infrastructural rooms. Offerors must also include other interior drawings that include, but are not limited to, a typical floor plan, typical office layout, roof plan, etc. These determinations will be made by the leasing project team in close collaboration with the Chief Architect or designee.) DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 11 of 22 The Chief Architect or designee plays a significant role in the development of the design criteria and technical evaluation factors for lease construction source selection. The Chief Architect or designee may be a voting member of the SSEB, and the Chief Architect or designee are available to offer guidance to the LCO. The SSEB will evaluate site and facility designs. The Source Selection Plan (SSP) provides guidance for developing the RLP, identifying evaluation factors and methods used in evaluating proposals. The LCO works with the leasing project team to develop the SSP and receives technical assistance from the SSEB in such development. The SSEB should review the SSP before the presolicitation conference and before RLP issuance. FEMA Headquarters, Winchester, VA DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 12 of 22 SOURCE SELECTION IN FURTHER DETAIL - 4 After the determination of a Single Phase BVTO or Two- Phase Design Build BVTO for procurement, the Chief Architect or designee shall work with the LCO to develop evaluation factors and design requirements for the RLP and SSP. EVALUATION FACTORS AND REQUIREMENTS Evaluation factors may include, but are not limited to site, design, and offeror/team qualifications. The RLP will define the minimum requirements for each evaluation factor. In addition to the minimum RLP requirements, important evaluation factors affecting the building design need to be evaluated. These may include:   How the site supports program requirements (i.e., capacity, expansion)   Zoning and anticipated usage.   Site ownership and/or control.   Environmental and regulatory compliance.   A/E firm and lead designer s completion of projects of similar size and complexity.   Capacity of surrounding infrastructure, e.g., transportation, roads, utilities.   Surrounding amenities, e.g., shops, childcare, food service, hospitality, etc.   Ability of the facility s design and layout to support customer s operational requirements.   Other minimum requirements as stated in the RLP. Design requirements are typically tailored to the needs of the project. They are based on the level of design required pre- or post-award and extent of designer qualifications. A/E FIRM AND LEAD DESIGNER S QUALIFICATIONS An offeror s entire design team must demonstrate its ability to satisfy the comprehensive project development and management requirements of the RLP. The qualifications information submitted by offerors can be basic or extensive; such breadth depends on the level and complexity of the project. This information encompasses both experience and past performance. Experience refers to offeror-submitted information about completed projects, whereas past performance is gathered via checks of references provided by the offeror on how well those projects were completed. DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 13 of 22 Commented [2]: correct formatting Design Philosophy and Approach of the lead designer is one other factor to be evaluated as part of the RLP process. Evaluation of design philosophy and approach may include, but are not limited the following elements:   Understanding of the Government s requirements.   Demonstration of creativity and innovation in meeting those requirements.   Balancing design with budget limitations.   Integration of the site and surrounding environment.   Application of current sustainability and energy-efficiency requirements. Evaluation of the lead designer s experience, includes, but is not limited to: successful completion of at least three projects similar in size, complexity, and scope in the last 10 years. Evaluation of Past Performance is based on reference checks of the offeror and key personnel (i.e. the A/E and Lead Designer) when requested although there are cases in which SSEBs have specified reference checks for entities such as the offeror s project manager and general contractor. Past performance reference checks are not a guarantee of future design quality. The past performance should evaluate the design portfolio of the A/E firm and lead designer in terms of:   Cost control   Timeliness of performance   Business relations   Technical quality of the service performed   Small business subcontracting DESIGN SUBMITTAL REVIEW AND EVALUATION SSEB s typically evaluates A/E and lead designer s qualifications, as well as design teams , site and design analyses. In addition, design evaluation criteria are identified, defined, and communicated to offerors in the RLP. Examples of design evaluation criteria may include:   Ease of accessibility (e.g., curb cuts, condition of route).   Weather protection (covered and climate-controlled areas).   Visual and physical security.   Building efficiency (RU factor).   Floor plate efficiency (RU factor).   Building form supports the function of the tenant agency, (e.g., space allocations reflect the documented needs of occupants).   Building form expresses the mission and goals of the tenant agency. DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 14 of 22   Workspace quality: team areas, open/closed offices.   Finished ceiling height in feet.   Percent of glazing on the building envelope   Percent of exterior obstructed by adjacent buildings. Sustainability POST-AWARD DESIGN ACTIVITIES Depending on the procurement method used, the level of design completed prior to lease award varies significantly. Defining the post-award design process and other design activities is therefore a fundamental task of a leasing project team. The team s description must encompass design, construction documents, and construction/refurbishment. It must also specify the number and type of design reviews, topics, and designated decision makers, along with specific outcomes and objectives of each review session. The input of the team s Chief Architect or designee is fundamental to this effort. After a lease award, the PM should conduct a Post Award Kickoff meeting with the successful offeror to define the roles, scope, and authority for the project s design process. The customer agency must be present at this meeting, while the offeror s representatives, PM, LCO, PBS Office of Facility Management representative, Chief Architect or designee, and any other necessary participants should attend, as well. The Chief Architect or designee shall continue to play a significant role in the design process after lease award, because achieving a successful, well-designed building is an ongoing process. Management of the detailed design, construction, build-out, and occupancy of the new leased space should abide by the terms that the leasing project team defines in the RLP and Lease Agreement. Federal Bureau of Investigation Field Office (FBI), Chicago Illinois DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 15 of 22 DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 16 of 22 APPENDIX - 1 PROJECT TEAM (PARTICIPANTS): ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Assembling the project team and defining its members  roles is an important first step in any complex project. When it is known that Lease Construction will be the approved lease acquisition direction, the PM or LCO will engage the Chief Architect or designee as a member of the project team. The project team also includes the LS and subject matter experts representing architecture, engineering, interior design and other subject matter experts as necessary. The Office of Leasing assists federal agencies in accomplishing their mission by providing lease acquisition services that deliver space on time, at the best value, and with superior solutions. The Regional Leasing Office determines the project lead for a Lease Construction project. The designated project lead (the PM, LCO, or LS) will engage the Chief Architect or designee on all new building construction lease projects. Project Managers (PMs) oversee management of the most complex projects. They have overall project-management responsibility for assigned projects from preliminary identification through initiation, planning, execution, and project- closeout stages. The PM s broad managerial responsibilities encompass planning and requirements development, as well as organizing, controlling, coordinating, reviewing, and approving design, construction, project delivery, and related work. The PM shepherds a project to implementation, and serves as a key resource during all stages of execution. If there is a PM assigned to a project, then the LCO becomes a team member on the leasing project team. Whether the PM or LCO serves as the project lead, that person must contact the Chief Architect or designee early in a Lease Construction project s development process. The Leasing Contracting Officer (LCO) has exclusive authority to enter into, amend, and administer leases on the Government s behalf to the extent provided in his or her certificate of appointment as a contracting officer. The LCO safeguards the interests of the United States in its lease acquisition program, processes, and policies. The Leasing Specialist (LS) assists the LCO and may perform duties that do not legally obligate the Government. GSA has established guidelines regarding the issues that a LS must consider when allocating resources to support the design, construction, and project management phases of projects (e.g., size, complexity, availability of local GSA associates, and/or IDIQ DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 17 of 22 contractors). The Office of Design and Construction, which includes the Office of the Chief Architect and the Office of Project Delivery, provides national leadership in design and construction expertise. in architecture, engineering, and construction project management support GSA s regional offices coordinating policies, procedures, initiatives, and sharing best practices. Its trusted experts The Chief Architect, in coordination with Regional Chief Architects (RCA s) and DE-Leasing National Program Director, oversees GSA's implementation of the national DE Program and partners with the Office of Leasing concerning implementation of DE-Leasing. The Chief Architect represents agency-wide standards of quality through multiple programs that include DE. The DE-LNPD ensures that GSA s national design policy is applied to regional projects. The DE-LNPD supports the integration of DE-Leasing into projects. Depending upon project complexity, the DE-LNPD may offer suggestions for Central Office SMEs to act as advisors to the SSEB. The DE-LNPD is a key resource in the design approach. The DE-LNPD, upon RCA request, may also contribute to requirements development and any post award design issues that may arise. The RCA ensures that GSA s national design policy is applied to regional projects, by engaging with Lease Construction projects from initial scoping and kickoff through the design development phase and/or early construction documents. The RCA may be designated as a project team member for all Lease Construction projects in their specific region. The RCA supports the integration of DE-Leasing into projects by: providing design submittal criteria for the LCO to use in the evaluation factors; reviewing proposed RLP content related to design and participating in design submittal evaluations. Depending upon project complexity, the RCA may offer suggestions for Regional SME s to act as advisors to the SSEB. RCA s are a key resource in procurement and design approach for A/E selection and design review. RCA involvement may not be limited to the project s initial design phase. These team members may also contribute to requirements development and any post award design issues that may arise. They may also participate in DESIGN EXCELLENCE IN LEASING PROGRAM GUIDANCE 2021 18 of 22 market surveys, reviews of tenant improvement (TI) costs, design, build-outs, and construction inspections in summary, these GSA staff experts draw on their specialized knowledge to assist the whole lease acquisition process. SMEs  knowledge areas include, but are not limited to accessibility, DE-Leasing policies and procedures, engineering, fire and life safety, historic preservation, sustainability, and workplace design. Regional Workplace Executives (RWE s) are another resource internal to GSA, as they work in concert with the Chief Architect or designee to support the leasing project team as necessary. RWE specialties include interior space design, procurement approach, DID (design intent drawings), and design review for TIs. RWEs partner with stakeholders to create customized workplace programs, which focus on mobile strategies and flexible environments that help agencies meet their business, sustainability, and real estate goals. results.EO_Text: Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents 8621 Presidential Documents Executive Order 14170 of January 20, 2025 Reforming the Federal Hiring Process and Restoring Merit to Government Service By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, including sections 3301, 3302, and 7511 of title 5, United States Code, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Policy. American citizens deserve an excellent and efficient Federal workforce that attracts the highest caliber of civil servants committed to achieving the freedom, prosperity, and democratic rule that our Constitution promotes. But current Federal hiring practices are broken, insular, and out- dated. They no longer focus on merit, practical skill, and dedication to our Constitution. Federal hiring should not be based on impermissible factors, such as one s commitment to illegal racial discrimination under the guise of  equity,  or one s commitment to the invented concept of  gender iden- tity  over sex. Inserting such factors into the hiring process subverts the will of the People, puts critical government functions at risk, and risks losing the best-qualified candidates. By making our recruitment and hiring processes more efficient and focused on serving the Nation, we will ensure that the Federal workforce is prepared to help achieve American greatness, and attracts the talent necessary to serve our citizens effectively. By significantly improving hiring principles and practices, Americans will receive the Federal resources and services they deserve from the highest-skilled Federal workforce in the world. Sec. 2. Federal Hiring Plan. (a) Within 120 days of the date of this order, the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, and the Administrator of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), shall develop and send to agency heads a Federal Hiring Plan that brings to the Federal workforce only highly skilled Americans dedicated to the furtherance of American ideals, values, and interests. (b) This Federal Hiring Plan shall: (i) prioritize recruitment of individuals committed to improving the effi- ciency of the Federal government, passionate about the ideals of our American republic, and committed to upholding the rule of law and the United States Constitution; (ii) prevent the hiring of individuals based on their race, sex, or religion, and prevent the hiring of individuals who are unwilling to defend the Constitution or to faithfully serve the Executive Branch; (iii) implement, to the greatest extent possible, technical and alternative assessments as required by the Chance to Compete Act of 2024; (iv) decrease government-wide time-to-hire to under 80 days; (v) improve communication with candidates to provide greater clarity regarding application status, timelines, and feedback, including regular updates on the progress of applications and explanations of hiring decisions where appropriate; (vi) integrate modern technology to support the recruitment and selection process, including the use of data analytics to identify trends, gaps, and VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:45 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00001 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE9.SGM 30JAE9 5 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l 8622 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents opportunities in hiring, as well as leveraging digital platforms to improve candidate engagement; and (vii) ensure Department and Agency leadership, or their designees, are active participants in implementing the new processes and throughout the full hiring process. (c) This Federal Hiring Plan shall include specific agency plans to improve the allocation of Senior Executive Service positions in the Cabinet agencies, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Office of Management and Budget, the Small Business Administration, the Social Security Administration, the National Science Foundation, the Office of Personnel Management, and the General Services Administration, to best facilitate democratic leadership, as required by law, within each agency. (d) The Federal Hiring Plan shall provide specific best practices for the human resources function in each agency, which each agency head shall implement, with advice and recommendations as appropriate from DOGE. Sec. 3. Accountability and Reporting. (a) The Director of the Office of Per- sonnel Management shall establish clear performance metrics to evaluate the success of these reforms, and request agency analysis on a regular basis. (b) The Office of Personnel Management shall consult with Federal agen- cies, labor organizations, and other stakeholders to monitor progress and ensure that the reforms are meeting the needs of both candidates and agencies. Sec. 4. General Provisions. (a) Nothing in this order shall be construed to impair or otherwise affect: (i) the authority granted by law to an executive department, agency, or the head thereof; (ii) the functions of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget relating to budgetary, administrative, or legislative proposals; or (iii) the functions of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or the Federal Open Market Committee relating to its conduct of monetary policy. (b) This order shall be implemented consistent with applicable law and subject to the availability of appropriations. 5 1 C O D Z E R P _ R F h t i w D O R P 3 2 N Q X 1 1 K S D n o r e t t o l VerDate Sep<11>2014 18:45 Jan 29, 2025 Jkt 265001 PO 00000 Frm 00002 Fmt 4790 Sfmt 4790 E:\FR\FM\30JAE9.SGM 30JAE9 Federal Register / Vol. 90, No. 19 / Thursday, January 30, 2025 / Presidential Documents 8623 (c) This order is not intended to, and does not, create any right or benefit, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity by any party against the United States, its departments, agencies, or entities, its officers, employees, or agents, or any other person. THE WHITE HOUSE, January 20, 2025. results.Summary:
Policy Analysis Summary

1. Policy Summary (Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance 2021):
The document outlines GSA's Design Excellence (DE) program for lease acquisitions involving new building construction. It provides a comprehensive framework for:
- Incorporating design excellence into lease acquisitions
- Defining roles and responsibilities of project team members
- Establishing source selection criteria
- Ensuring high-quality design and construction for federal leased facilities

2. Executive Order Summary:
Executive Order 14170 focuses on reforming the federal hiring process by:
- Developing a new Federal Hiring Plan within 120 days
- Prioritizing recruitment of individuals committed to government efficiency
- Implementing new hiring practices and technologies
- Reducing time-to-hire
- Improving candidate communication
- Ensuring leadership involvement in hiring processes

3. Applicability of Executive Order:
The executive order primarily affects hiring practices and does not directly impact the substantive content of the Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance. 

Key points of non-interference:
- The policy document is about leasing and design processes
- The executive order focuses on hiring and recruitment
- No specific provisions in the order suggest changes to leasing or design procedures

4. Compliance Recommendations:
While no direct policy changes are required, GSA should:
- Review hiring practices for Design Excellence program team members
- Ensure recruitment aligns with new federal hiring guidelines
- Prepare for potential changes in staffing and recruitment for leasing and design teams
- Monitor further guidance from the Office of Personnel Management

Conclusion: The executive order does not substantively affect the Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance. Standard monitoring and potential minor administrative adjustments are recommended.
results.updated_summary: The executive order focuses on hiring practices and does not contain provisions that would substantively modify the Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance. The policy's core architectural and design standards remain unaltered by this workforce-focused executive order.
results.phase1_response:
## Policy Analysis: Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance vs. Executive Order 14170

### 1. Brief Summary of Policy Text

The Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance (DE-LPG) 2021 is a GSA policy document that establishes frameworks and procedures for applying design excellence principles to certain lease procurements, specifically "Lease Construction" involving new building construction. The policy updates the 2001 guidance and ensures expert-informed decision-making in design, construction, and project delivery processes for leased federal facilities. It focuses on delivering best customer value through superior quality outcomes that are on time, on budget, and within scope.

### 2. Brief Summary of Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14170, issued January 20, 2025, aims to reform federal hiring processes by focusing on merit-based selection. The order explicitly prohibits consideration of factors such as commitment to "equity" (characterized as illegal racial discrimination) and "gender identity" concepts in hiring decisions. It mandates the development of a Federal Hiring Plan within 120 days, involving the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy, OMB Director, OPM Director, and the Administrator of the Department of Government Efficiency.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Executive Order Applicability

**The executive order does NOT directly apply to the DE-LPG policy.** Here's the detailed analysis:

**Scope Mismatch:**
- The executive order specifically targets federal hiring processes and personnel selection
- The DE-LPG policy addresses project delivery, design standards, and procurement procedures for leased facilities
- These are fundamentally different operational domains

**Subject Matter Distinction:**
- Executive Order 14170 focuses on human resources practices and civil service recruitment
- DE-LPG focuses on real estate transactions, design excellence standards, and construction project management
- No overlap exists in the core subject matters

**Implementation Realm:**
- The executive order affects HR departments and hiring managers
- DE-LPG affects real estate professionals, project managers, and design teams
- Different GSA divisions would implement these respective policies

**Potential Indirect Considerations:**
While the core DE-LPG policy remains unaffected, any future updates to the guidance should ensure that if personnel selection criteria are incorporated (such as for design review panels or consultant selection), those criteria align with merit-based principles outlined in the executive order.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

Since the policy is not directly affected, no immediate compliance actions are required for the DE-LPG itself. However, GSA should consider these precautionary measures:

- **Monitoring:** Stay alert for any future executive orders or implementing guidance that might affect procurement or project delivery policies
- **Review Protocols:** If the DE-LPG is updated in the future, ensure any personnel-related provisions align with federal hiring reform principles
- **Documentation:** Maintain awareness that related policies involving contractor selection or consultant evaluation should comply with merit-based criteria

**Final Determination: [Not Affected]**

results.phase2_response:
**Step 1: Policy Domain Identification**
The policy "Design Excellence in Leasing Program Guidance" operates in the domain of federal real estate management, specifically focusing on GSA's leasing processes, design standards, building performance, and project delivery for federal facilities.

**Step 2: Executive Order Domain Identification**
Executive Order 14170 "Reforming the Federal Hiring Process and Restoring Merit to Government Service" operates in the domain of federal human resources management, specifically addressing hiring practices, merit-based selection, and personnel policies across federal agencies.

**Step 3: Domain Comparison and Impact Assessment**
These are fundamentally different operational domains:
- The policy governs **physical infrastructure** (buildings, leases, design processes)
- The executive order governs **human capital** (hiring, personnel selection, workforce composition)

While both involve GSA operations, they address entirely separate functional areas with no substantive overlap in their core purposes or implementation mechanisms.

**Step 4: Independent Assessment Context**
The phase1_flag of "Not Affected" aligns with the clear domain separation. There are no obvious connection points between federal hiring reform and real estate leasing guidance.

**Final Decision: [Not Affected]**

**Full Justification:**

1. **Policy Domain:** Federal real estate leasing and facility design excellence, encompassing GSA's Design Excellence Program, building performance standards, project delivery processes, and leasing policies.

2. **Executive Order Domain:** Federal personnel management reform, specifically hiring processes, merit-based selection criteria, and workforce composition policies.

3. **Impact Analysis:** There is no direct or meaningful indirect impact. The executive order addresses "who gets hired" while the policy addresses "how buildings are leased and designed." These are operationally distinct functions:
   - The leasing guidance governs contractual relationships with private sector lessors and design standards
   - The hiring reform affects internal GSA staffing decisions but not the substantive content of leasing policies

4. **Supporting Language:** The EO focuses on "Federal hiring practices," "merit," and "civil servants," while the policy centers on "design excellence," "building performance," and "project delivery." No provisions in the EO directly reference or impact real estate operations.

5. **Nuances Considered:** While GSA staff involved in leasing decisions are federal employees subject to hiring reforms, this represents an extremely attenuated connection. The policy's substantive requirements (design standards, leasing procedures, performance criteria) remain completely independent of hiring process changes. Personnel changes might affect implementation capacity but do not alter the policy's substantive content or requirements.

The domains are sufficiently distinct that federal hiring reform has no meaningful bearing on real estate leasing guidance.

results.Policy Text: U.S. General Services Administration Equity Action Plan Updates for 2023 U.S. General Services Administration Message from Administrator Robin C. Carnahan The General Services Administration s overarching goal is delivering efficient, effective government for the American people. As we look to the future, we re codifying another element into that goal: equity. The sacred trust between government and its citizens should inform every action, every decision, and every policy. It s our responsibility to get people the services they need, when they need them   that s why we re taking a people-centered approach to government. We know that government only works when it works for everyone, so I m proud to renew GSA s commitment to delivering a government that s equitable, accessible, and inclusive of the diverse nation we serve. GSA has a big role to play in fulfilling the mission of government, whether we re investing in American jobs, partnering with American industry and trade labor, delivering digital government with good customer experience, building a more sustainable future, or bolstering the strength of communities across the country. In all this, we re committed to making meaningful equity impacts, recognizing that equitable approaches lead to better outcomes for everyone. That s why our Equity Action Plan is so important. The heart of this plan is community and it provides us with ways we can both transform government in the long-term and ensure that what the government delivers has meaningful impacts on the daily lives of people all across the country. The good news is that we have the money and the momentum to make these kinds of impacts real. From Day One, the President has been focused on Investing in America   in our people, in our infrastructure, and in rebuilding our economy through historic, once-in-a-generation investments. I ve been out on the road a lot this year and I ve seen these strategies in action firsthand. To start, with over $6 billion from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and Inflation Reduction Act, we re making smart investments in GSA-controlled Federal buildings all across the country. We re focused on building spaces that are part of the communities they inhabit, modernizing them so they can easily provide services to the American people, and ensuring their resilience and sustainability. With every investment, we re seeking to address climate change because it s a triple win: creating good jobs, saving taxpayer dollars, and making a healthier future for generations to come. We know that historically underserved communities are too-often disproportionately impacted by climate change, so we re making sure that this triple win benefits everyone. 1 U.S. General Services Administration From Arizona to Ohio, I ve heard from workers that are proud to be part of this national transformation and that they see the benefits to their families, their communities, and American businesses. I ve met with trade labor unions, workers, and leaders in the building and construction industry, all of whom have shared with me how they re committed to these same goals. They re recruiting more women and people of color and training them in the tools and technologies we need to implement billions of dollars in investments. They know what we know: these investments will create pathways to the middle-class, strengthen communities across the country, and build a stronger and more prosperous future for everyone. At our federal buildings, we ve been partnering with local small businesses to guide them through the process of accessing opportunities across the Federal marketplace. We ve also been partnering with opportunity centers to raise awareness of these projects among the local communities. There s one location in D.C. where we ve helped over 35 businesses get onto government schedules and helped secure jobs for over 2,500 people. We re also focused on the physical accessibility of our buildings through our National Accessibility Program, the many efforts of our Office of Design and Construction, and our long-standing relationship with the U.S. Access Board. We also partnered with Challenge.gov to launch the  Access for All  universal and accessible design competition for U.S. architecture students to source best practice improvements. As the caretaker of the nation s largest public art collection, we ve preserved and expanded the people s collection over the last 50 years, placing art in Federal buildings and public spaces that tells the story of our nation and our democracy. We re committed to expanding opportunities for new artists to contribute, creating jobs while ensuring that the diversity and vibrancy of our portfolio reflects the diversity and vibrancy of the American story. Our Federal Acquisition Service and Office of Small & Disadvantaged Business Utilization are committed to making it easier for businesses to succeed in the Federal marketplace. From forecasting tools and new identifiers for a diverse range of businesses to training and outreach programs, we re actively expanding our supplier diversity, reducing barriers, and improving outcomes. In fact, GSA awarded more than $3.3 billion to small businesses, which represents over 50% of the agency's FY23 eligible spending, according to data current as of November 2, 2023. GSA s work delivering  services that are simple to use, accessible, equitable, protective, transparent, and responsive for all people  is evident in our digital capabilities as well. Our public-facing websites are 508 compliant, support assistive technology, and are available in multiple languages. In fact, Vote.gov has recently added its first Alaska Native language and multiple Asian American Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander languages to increase accessibility while supporting cultural vitality. We re also 2 U.S. General Services Administration engaging in equity studies across our Technology Transformation Services to ensure that we re providing human-centered tools that meet the needs of every American. We ve been partnering across the government as well. Our Office of Government-wide Policy IT Accessibility team helps agencies meet Federal compliance standards while our U.S. Web Design Services offers toolkits and best practices to ensure that Federal websites are accessible for everyone   that includes providing specific resources to support customers in varying socio-economic communities. Through our work with the Department of Labor s Good Jobs Initiative, we re helping improve job quality and create access to good union jobs free from discrimination and harassment for all working people, with an emphasis on people of color, LGBTQ+, women, veterans, immigrants, individuals in rural communities, and individuals with disabilities. Finally, we ve been committed to strengthening ties and trust between Tribal Nations and the United States. From attending the Reservation Economic Summit and hosting our first Native Nations Industry Day at GSA Headquarters to holding nation-to-nation consultations and visiting with Tribal leaders and communities, we re building Nation-to- Nation partnerships so that our work in Indian Country strengthens businesses and communities. Looking to the future, GSA s updated action plan aims to further advance equity through the agency s high-impact program areas like Federal procurement, Federal buildings, and Federal technology design and delivery. It also gives increased emphasis to GSA s role in helping to strengthen the government s ability to be more agile, responsive, and reflective of Americans  needs through evaluation and data-driven insights. By focusing on these five strategies, GSA will use its unique position of delivering mission-critical services and core products across government to act as a force multiplier in advancing equity and reducing burdens for underserved communities. That is what good government is all about   and GSA is proud to do our part to strengthen our democracy and foster more trust between the Federal Government and the American people. Robin C. Carnahan Administrator, U.S. General Services Administration 3 U.S. General Services Administration Advancing Equity Through Agency Mission The mission of the U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) is to deliver the best customer experience and value in real estate, acquisition, and technology services to the government and the American people. As we work to meet our goals of delivery on behalf of the government, we are only meeting our mission as a federal agency if the American people can equitably benefit from our efforts. That means that as GSA leverages its over $85 billion buying power to provide Federal purchasers with cost-effective, high-quality products and services from commercial vendors, we are also advancing the diversity of the American supplier base and economic security for small businesses. When we provide critical technology services and modernizations, GSA has a mission to ensure that digital government is reflective of and designed to perform for all the diverse communities we serve. As GSA plans and completes large scale construction projects across our 375 million rentable square feet of Federal real estate, we do so in a manner that is informed by local communities to ensure that the sustainability, vitality and livability made possible through Federal investment is available to every American neighborhood. GSA s mission is government delivery   and that includes delivering on the American promise of equal opportunity, civil rights, and justice for all. Executive Summary In response to Executive Order 14091 on Further Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government, the U.S. General Services Administration has undertaken an agenda to operationalize equity across its public-facing mission critical programs and services. Not only do these updated strategies build on the successes and learnings from our 2022 Equity Action Plan, they further integrate cross-cutting equity goals in important and impactful ways. Deeper synergies are possible to realize across priorities related to economic justice, sustainable and equitable development, customer experience and digital government, gender equity, environmental justice, protecting civil rights, and support for an ecosystem of sociodemographic community groups, Tribes, and institutions. Another core tenet of this plan is GSA s commitment to expanding Federal interagency coordination and advancing meaningful engagement with the public when it matters most and can make a difference. This collaborative posture reflects GSA s unique role in government as an agency that supports other agencies in their mission success. GSA s business is the business of government - whether that is helping buyers and sellers connect more efficiently and equitably in Federal marketplaces, modernizing and delivering high-impact digital solutions, challenging industry to join us in tackling the climate crisis through sustainable supply chain innovations, or driving the revitalization of American neighborhoods by putting people to work in their communities with good jobs paid for by once-in-a-generation infrastructure investments. This plan outlines five strategies to advance and embed equity in Fiscal Year (FY) 2024:   Advance Equity, Economic Justice, and the Diversity of the American Supplier Base through Federal Procurement. This strategy supports the whole-of-government equity objective of economic justice; and it aims to address barriers faced by small and disadvantaged businesses as they participate in the Federal marketplace. Key actions are designed to improve contracting efficiency and success through data insights, innovative procurement tools, and greater collaboration across Federal agencies. 4 U.S. General Services Administration   Deliver Equitable, Accessible and Inclusive Digital Government to the American Public. This strategy supports the whole-of-government equity objectives of Economic Justice and Civil Rights; and it aims to address potential barriers and biases present in public interactions with civic tech. Key actions include advancing human centered design and community-informed user research practices, scaling language access, and ensuring responsible adoption and procurement of AI-enabled technologies.   Advance Equity, Economic Security, Sustainability and Environmental Justice through Large-Scale Construction Projects and the Federal Buildings Footprint. This strategy supports the whole-of-government equity objectives of Economic Justice, Environmental Justice, and Housing Justice and Community Investment; and it aims to address barriers to community benefits realized through equitable and sustainable Federal development. Key actions are designed to improve planning and access to local opportunities - like good jobs and cleaner, more climate change-resilient communities, made possible by landmark Bipartisan Infrastructure Law and Inflation Reduction Act investments.   Advance Equity and Effectiveness of Federal Programs Through Rigorous Review, Evaluation and Continuous Improvement. This strategy supports the whole- of-government equity objectives of Civil Rights, Health Equity, Economic Justice, Global Equality; and it aims to ensure Federal programs are working as intended, particularly programs that provide critical support to the public during emergencies and recovery after disasters. Key actions include scaling the Federal Government s use of evaluations to surface important findings and areas of improvement in the design and delivery of Federal programs.   Advance Equitable Access to Opportunity and Federal Resources for Local Communities and Minority Serving Institutions. This strategy supports the whole-of- government equity objectives of Civil Rights and Economic Justice; and it aims to reduce barriers to access for institutions that, through Federal resources, help close critical gaps in capacity and infrastructure for the local communities they serve. Key actions include conducting proactive civil rights compliance reviews of the Federal Surplus Personal Property Donation Program and broadening partnerships - including contracting agreements - between Federal agencies and Minority Serving Institutions. Approaches to the five strategies are meant to be tactical and have measurable outcomes. At the heart of these strategies are the American people   particularly those who are overcoming systemic burdens, have been locked out of a fair chance at opportunities or are disproportionately in the path of harm when disaster strikes. GSA has developed our agency actions to reflect the needs of the people, identified through data and feedback collected in our own regular engagement and evaluation practices and with the help of thoughtfully researched insights generated from trusted industry experts and Federal partners. 5 U.S. General Services Administration Equity Progress Updates and Accomplishments 2022 Equity Action Plan Update In January 2022, GSA released its inaugural Equity Action Plan in accordance with Executive Order 13985: Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government. To develop this plan, GSA conducted equity assessments and identified a set of actions for three high-impact program areas: Federal procurement, Federal buildings footprint, and Federal technology design and delivery. The section below provides an overview of the key accomplishments achieved since publication of the original Equity Action Plan. Advancing Equity and Supplier Diversity in Federal Procurement   In FY 2022, $2.8 billion of GSA contracting obligations went to small businesses, including 21.4% to small disadvantaged businesses (SDBs); In FY 2023, GSA increased its small business contracting obligations to $3.3 billion, representing over 50% of the agency s eligible spending.   Launched a new Supplier Base Dashboard to provide more transparency and public reporting on Federal efforts to increase the number of new entrants to the Federal marketplace and reverse the general decline in the small business supplier base.   Signed a new 8(a) partnership agreement with the U.S. Small Business Administration to increase 8(a) contracting opportunities and make it easier for Federal agencies to buy from 8(a) businesses for common goods and services needs.   Established new contracting pools in the growing Federal marketplace of Information Technology services and solutions to bolster participation of Women-Owned Small Business, Service-Disabled Veteran- Owned Small Business, and small businesses located in Historically Underutilized Business Zones. The 8(a) STARS III contracts have been awarded to 1,111 SDB. 290  rising stars  have received their first awards exceeding $925 million in obligations.   Expanded tools to support Minority Serving Institutions with training and technical assistance to achieve success in the Federal contracting marketplace.   Established a Post-Award Engagement strategy to support disadvantaged and socioeconomic small businesses, which oftentimes still face challenges in successfully earning sales after being awarded a GSA contract.   Published the first-ever Supplier Diversity Plan to support Federal marketplace participation of SDB.   Updated the Multiple Award Schedule Welcome Package and Roadmap to improve information access and assist new contractors with success in marketing and managing their contracts. 6 Advancing Equity and Accessibility in Federal Technology U.S. General Services Administration   Launched an Equity Study on Remote Identity, recruiting 4,000 Americans, to understand potential barriers and demographic disparities in identity verification technologies that are commonly used by the public when accessing Federal services and benefits.
